feed.title: Combined summary - DahLIAS: Discrete Logarithm-Based Interactive Aggregate Signatures

entry.title: Combined summary - DahLIAS: Discrete Logarithm-Based Interactive Aggregate Signatures
entry.summary:
The recent paper authored by Jonas Nick, Tim Ruffing, and Yannick Seurin has introduced DahLIAS, a groundbreaking interactive aggregate signature scheme compatible with secp256k1. This development represents a significant leap forward in cryptographic protocols, offering the first constant-size signatures (64 bytes) designed to facilitate Cross-Input Signature Aggregation (CISA). Such an advancement is particularly valuable for Bitcoin transactions, enabling more efficient transaction sizes and verification costs by allowing each signer to contribute their own message. This feature sets it apart from traditional multi- and threshold signature schemes that require all signers to endorse a single message.
Previously, efforts to create constant-size aggregate signatures encountered various obstacles, including reliance on cryptographic assumptions divergent from those underpinning Bitcoin's secp256k1 signatures, as well as a lack of comprehensive descriptions and security validations. The DahLIAS scheme addresses these issues by providing a secure, efficient framework while affirming the security of certain constructions that were speculative before, specifically in scenarios where key tweaking is avoided.
A notable vulnerability in other aggregate signature schemes derived from MuSig2 was their incompatibility with key tweaking. DahLIAS distinguishes itself by overcoming this challenge, thereby enhancing its applicability and reliability. The operational efficiency of DahLIAS is further underscored by its streamlined two-round communication process for signing, wherein the initial round does not necessitate knowledge of the messages to be signed. Moreover, DahLIAS signatures can be verified twice as fast as half aggregate Schnorr signatures, and even more swiftly in batch verifications compared to individual Schnorr signatures. This efficiency makes DahLIAS an exceptionally promising component for future CISA implementations.
The authors of the paper, accessible at [eprint.iacr.org](https://eprint.iacr.org/2025/692.pdf), have expressed their eagerness for feedback and discussions. Their commitment to refining cryptographic solutions within the Bitcoin ecosystem highlights the potential for DahLIAS to significantly impact future developments in the field.
